summary: Internal email correspondence within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the assignment of a paralegal to support the forfeiture side of the Epstein case. The email chain involves unit co-chiefs discussing administrative case support.

persons.name: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit
persons.context: Responds to an inquiry about assigning a paralegal to the Epstein case for forfeiture support, indicating that a paralegal will be assigned to handle forfeiture matters.

persons.name: Co-Chief, Public Corruption Unit
persons.context: Initiates the email inquiry asking if a paralegal will be assigned to work on the Epstein case, indicating oversight of case administration.

connections.person2: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit
connections.description: Colleagues within the U.S. Attorney's Office coordinating on administrative support for the Epstein case, specifically regarding paralegal assignment for forfeiture matters.

events.title: Inquiry about Epstein case paralegal assignment
events.description: Co-Chief of the Public Corruption Unit emails to ask if a paralegal will be assigned to work on the Epstein case.

events.title: Confirmation of paralegal assignment for Epstein forfeiture
events.description: Co-Chief of the Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit confirms that a paralegal will be assigned to support the forfeiture side of the Epstein case.
personsInvolved: Co-Chief, Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York was actively managing the Epstein case as of June 2019, including planning for asset forfeiture proceedings.
A paralegal was to be assigned specifically to support the forfeiture side of the Epstein case, indicating anticipated asset seizures.
The email correspondence shows internal coordination between the Public Corruption Unit and the Money Laundering and Transnational Criminal Enterprises Unit regarding case administration.
The document references standard practice where paralegal support is assigned once assets are seized or someone is charged, suggesting the Epstein case met those criteria.
